Award.AwardTitle: New Catalysts for Electrochemical and Solar H2 Production
Award.AbstractNarration: The Chemical Catalysis Program supports Professor Richard Glass and his coworkers at the University of Arizona for investigations designed to develop cheap and efficient catalysts for storing energy from electricity in chemical bonds, particularly for the production of H2 from water. Design of catalysts inspired by exceptionally efficient hydrogenase enzymes containing earth abundant Fe and Ni centers are the focus of this work. New basic science in which organic redox centers are coupled with diiron and bimetallic catalytic centers will be explored. Complementary synthetic, spectroscopic characterization, and electrochemical evaluation studies will be carried out. Understanding of intramolecular electron-transfer will result from the mechanistic approach taken in this work. The development of novel catalytic materials, coupled with an understanding of how these materials operate in the solar energy driven generation of hydrogen, will result from these studies. These new materials could have a major impact on alternative energy production, and on the supply of clean sources of energy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching objective of this research is to meet the growing societal need for readily available and inexpensive energy sources and clean, sustainable fuels. This is a grand challenge with numerous scientific and technological barriers to solutions. For example, molecular hydrogen is a promising high energy fuel that must be produced, stored and transported. Our work has focussed on the production of molecular hydrogen. Specifically, the goal of our research is to develop catalysts based on inexpensive and abundant elements that convert electrical or solar energy into chemical energy in the form of molecular hydrogen. The stable, chemically stored energy can then be converted back into electrical energy in a fuel cell. The inspiration for the catalysts studied was the active site of naturally occurring hydrogenase enzymes that contain the abundant elements iron and sulfur. Our easily synthesized catalysts produce molecular hydrogen from weak acids electrochemically as well as photochemically. We have determined the rate of production of molecular hydrogen from some of these electrochemical catalysts and found that the rate is incredibly fast. This is an important advance toward our end goal. Also important is to develop catalysts with long lifetimes. We have studied factors that shorten the lifetimes in order to preclude them. One of these factors is homodimerization in which an intermediate reacts with starting catalyst to generate a dimer. We have found that increasing the acid concentration prevents the intermediate from reacting with starting catalyst resulting in efficient formation of molecular hydrogen and increased lifetime for the catalyst.
